boardgame.name: Eorathril
boardgame.description:
Old School Fantasy Roleplaying

From the back of the book:

From game designer Alan Bahr, comes an «old» roleplaying game. Eorathril is a collection of OSR mechanics, leveraging the classic old school d20 mechanics, forged into a new game that represents the storytelling style and martial roleplaying of yesteryore!

Designed to emulate classic fantasy literature, Eorathril has a martial bent, featuring brave swordmasters, daring knights, fierce barbarians, wise sages and much more! Subtle tweaks to the ruleset, and a compilation of carefully chosen mechanics add to the heroic feel of the game, as well as a very brief primer on Eorathril, the home fantasy campaign of Alan Bahr.

Grab your sword, heft your spear, and prepare for a game of heroic adventures!

boardgame.name: Parliament of Gears
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

STEP BOLDLY INTO THE MOURNLAND!

On the edge of the Mournland, tensions are rising between the frontier folk and renegade warforged loyal to the Lord of Blades. When salvage workers start to go missing, the Brelish army sends the adventurers into the Mournland to mount a rescue.

A Four-Hour Adventure for Tier 2 Characters.

Optimized for APL 8, this is the first in a trilogy of adventures, the Dogs of War storyline.

boardgame.name: All Good Dead Men
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Something treacherous has boarded the illustrious gambling ship the Albatross! The fate of the ship and its passengers is at risk with only a handful of brave adventurers to stand in the way. Will the adventurers stop this high-seas skullduggery? Or will greed and treachery rule the tides?

A Two-Hour adventure with two bonus objectives for Tier 1 Characters. Optimized for APL 3.

Included is a full-art pdf and a printer-friendly version.

boardgame.name: Oh, Not the Bees!
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The Albatross has an exciting and mysterious new attraction that’s sure to amaze crowds of all ages! However, before the attraction can premiere, terrible sea creatures board the ship and threaten the lives of the passengers and the crew. Can a brave group of adventurers get this ship back on course? Or will the Albatross be lost forever at the bottom of the sea?

A Two-Hour adventure with two bonus objectives for Tier 2 Characters. Optimized for APL 8.

boardgame.name: Stargazing on the Albatross
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The Albatross has seen a few setbacks in its previous voyages, but that won’t stop Dr. Jubal’s party boat! Captain Prince Glip Glop, the captain of the Albatross, is paying adventurers handsomely to provide extra security for the high-profile guests. What will you do when extraplanar party crashers show up to ruin the fun?

A Four-Hour Adventure with two bonus objectives for Tier 3 Characters. Optimized for APL 13.

boardgame.name: Deep Magic (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Command 700 New Spells for 5th Edition!

No matter how you slice it, magic is at the heart of fantasy—and nothing says magic like a massive tome of spells. This tome collects, updates, tweaks, and expands spells from years of the Deep Magic for Fifth Edition series—more than 700 new and revised spells. And it adds a lot more:

19 divine domains from Beer to Mountain and Speed to Winter;
13 new wizard specialties, such as the elementalist and the timekeeper;
6 new sorcerous origins, including the Aristocrat and the Farseer;
3 otherworldly patrons for warlocks, including the Sibyl;


expanded treatments of familiars and other wizardly servants;
and much more!
This 356-page tome is not just for wizards, warlocks, and sorcerers. Deep Magic also expands the horizons of what’s possible for bards, clerics, druids, and even rangers and paladins. It offers something new for every spellcasting class! With these new spells and options, your characters (or your villains) can become masters of winter magic, chaos magic, or shadow magic. Seek out hidden colleges and academies of lost lore. Learn new runes, hieroglyphs, and cantrips to break down the walls of reality, or just bend them a bit.

Deep Magic contains nothing but magic from start to finish!

boardgame.name: The Necroforge
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The Seer of Glister has discovered the location of an ancient temple with the only means to destroy the accursed Plaguestone.

Can the adventurers stay one step ahead of the mysterious Thang'ard, avoid hordes of angry goblinoids, and destroy the Plaguestone in time at The Necroforge?

A Two- to Four-Hour Adventure for Tier 2 Characters. Optimized for APL 8.

CCC-PRETZ-PLA03 The Necroforge was to premier at Pretzcon in April 2020, look for us again next year!

boardgame.name: Hordes of Thar: The Bloody Crescent
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Melvaunt’s guards are found dead in the barracks, the mark of an orcish murder god splattered on their walls. While the assassins are elusive, the Emerald Enclave has found a way to track them to their shadowy hold in the form of a strange hermit. Will the adventurers bring light to the situation or be lost in the dark?

A Four-Hour Adventure for Tier 2 Characters.

Optimized for APL 8.

boardgame.name: Mischief at the Festival
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The annual Magic and Gold Festival in Thentia has begun! Come watch some shows, eat some food, play some games, and solve a murder.

Mischief at the Festival consists of four 1-hour adventures for characters of levels 1 to 4 that take place in the city of Thentia during a large celebration. These are designed to work well as introductory adventures for new players and DMs, but are still exciting and challenging for experienced players. The combats are tuned for newer players, but every combat includes a suggested adjustment to make it more challenging for veteran players.

The adventure itself is extremely easy to run and showcases a wide variety of D&D play experiences, including urban exploration, dungeon delving, combat challenges, improvisational roleplay, mystery investigation, and minigames. All of the adventures can be played separately or together, in any order the players choose. Characters who play through all four adventures can level up through Tier 1 and reach level 5 by the end if they so wish.

boardgame.name: Loophole
boardgame.description:
Loophole is a battle royale on a 5 x 5 grid. Players control a game piece with 9 lives and an immortal ghost piece.

Dice are rolled to determine movement. Squares containing loopholes allow players to transport themselves around the grid. Players navigate opponent's game pieces, ghosts, and a mirror at the center of the board. If a player's life counter die reaches 0 - their game piece is removed from the board, however, their ghost piece remains in play. This offers players who can no longer win an opportunity to cause mischief and avenge their loss. The last player with their game piece on the grid wins.

A unique, optional element is the soundtrack. There are periodic cues in the audio that signal a player should lose a turn. When the soundtrack is over - the game is over. In this variation the player with the most remaining lives wins.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Murder at the Festival
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

CCC-MAG01-02: Murder at the Festival! A series of grisly murders threatens the festivities at the annual Magic and Gold Festival in Thentia! Can your group of adventurers uncover the source of the attacks and stop the murderer before they strike again?

A delightfully murderous two-four hour mystery adventure for characters level 5-10 (optimized for APL 8).

boardgame.name: Burst!
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The Eye of Lolth has been stolen from a Hillsfar Museum. A band of adventurers are sent to track down this holy item. On the way, they will face perils of the Underdark and a new type of monster, blessed by the son of Lolth, created to destroy the Free Peoples... and Lolth.

Enjoy this Tier 2 extravaganza. If you like Alien, then you'll love Burst!

boardgame.name: Road to Reconciliation
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The Eraka clan vowed to raid any caravan leaving Phlan until the high chieftain's daughter is returned from captivity. Can you prevent war between the Eraka and Algreth’s aggressive merchant company?

A Two to Four Hour Adventure for Tier 1 Characters. Optimized for APL 3.

Designed for Replay: A key decision in the beginning creates two paths, altering some key encounters.

Optimized for Online: All maps for encounters with detailed maps are included.

boardgame.name: Facades Undone
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Part 18 of the Song of Fates series

In Thentia, the illness seems to have subsided, and there is rioting demand for the walls to come down. However, something lurks in the wall that is a threat to the citizens. See where allegiances lie and find the hidden machinations for those interested in the power of Fate.

A Four to Six-Hour Adventure for Tier 2 Characters. Optimized for APL 8.

boardgame.name: 100 Random Room Descriptions - Volume 070
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Oftentimes we find ourselves sitting around the table, with a set adventure path before our players, and the inevitable happens. One player is overtaken with wanderlust and must check every location except the one set before them. No problem. Within this collection are 100 different location descriptions. Some empty, some inhabited, some are named locations, while others are a free-for-all of random rooms and stores. Whether catering to an over-adventurous role-player or just looking to generate a random location filled with different rooms this collection of location descriptions are categorized as a handy table capable of handling either situation.

How to Use This Book

Grab a set of percentile dice (d100) and roll to determine what the random room is that your players may have just entered. Caution as some of these rooms contain living creatures. Partner this table with any random encounter table and a random treasure table to create fully in-depth encounter So gather your players, roll your dice, and Adventure On!

boardgame.description:

One player is overtaken with wanderlust and must check every location except the one set before them. No problem. Within this collection are 100 different location descriptions. Some empty, some inhabited, some are named locations, while others are a free-for-all of random rooms and stores. Whether catering to an over-adventurous role-player or just looking to generate a random location filled with different rooms this collection of location descriptions are categorized as a handy table capable of handling either situation.

How to Use This Book

Grab a set of percentile dice (d100) and roll to determine what the random room is that your players may have just entered. Caution as some of these rooms contain living creatures. Partner this table with any random encounter table and a random treasure table to create fully in-depth encounter So gather your players, roll your dice, and Adventure On!

boardgame.name: Buru
boardgame.description:
In Buru, you are a noble of the 14th century Majapahit empire, a powerful thalassocracy (maritime kingdom) that presides over the Indonesian archipelago. At the orders of the king Hayam Wuruk and his vizier, the great Gajah Mada, you have set out across the sea to expand the great mandala of Majapahit through commerce and diplomacy. You and your fellow nobles have recently arrived at the remote island of Buru, eager to earn your place in history. Here, you will dispatch your parties to the island to explore, trade, and pay your respects as you compete to win over Buru's residents and ultimately gain the favor of the King himself.

Buru is a mid-weight, Euro-style board game for 1-4 players. Over five game rounds, you and your fellow players secretly deploy explorers to the four different regions of the island in order to gather resources, recruit islanders, set them to tasks, and pay tribute to the spirits revered there. The object of the game is to win the islanders' esteem. You can earn esteem in many ways, primarily by paying tribute, but also by pleasing elders, tasking local nobles, fulfilling the king's decrees, and holding a totem when any player pays tribute to that spirit.

At the end of the game, the player with the most esteem wins and is declared the new governor of Buru!

-description from designer

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

boardgame.name: 50 Cyber City Citizens
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This one page list contains 50 different citizens that you would find in a cyberpunk settings. Included in each entry is the following: Name (often a street alias), Gender and role, cyber enhancements, and weapon. Though everything is geared for a more realistic cyberpunk setting these individuals could also be easily used with cyberpunk/fantasy crossovers.

boardgame.name: 50 Cyber City Citizens 2
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This one page list contains 50 different citizens that you would find in a cyberpunk settings. Included in each entry is the following: Name (often a street alias), Gender and role, cyber enhancements, and weapon. Though everything is geared for a more realistic cyberpunk setting these individuals could also be easily used with cyberpunk/fantasy crossovers.

boardgame.name: Shitty Werewolf
boardgame.description:
Shitty Werewolf is a combination of lowbrow art and high concept meta commentary on the classic social party game Werewolf. If you know how to play Werewolf, you already know how to play Shitty Werewolf, but here’s a quick rundown of the rules…

Everyone is secretly a villager or a werewolf, and over a series of night/day rounds, the werewolves will secretly eat villagers at night while the whole town will execute someone every day. The villagers are trying to kill all the werewolves while the werewolves are trying to eat enough villagers to outnumber them before they are executed. The game requires a moderator to run things and with special powers can get really complicated, but the core is a very simple game based around arguing with each other.

Unlike traditional Werewolf, the roles/powers in Shitty Werewolf frequently break not just the conventions of the genre but also the basic play loop of the game itself all while exploring the social dynamics present in all group interactions. With roles like the “Socially Awkward Friend Who Hates Werewolf but Didn’t Want to Make a Fuss About It” and the “Mansplainer” games can start to unravel around the all-too-real social conventions and conversational baggage we bring to the experience of playing Werewolf. But this high mindedness is coupled with roles like the “Swearwolf” and the “Raccoon” that make it clear that this is still a game about being weird together, even if you might end up with some deep thoughts along the way.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: 100 High School Kids 14
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This list contains 100 different kids you would find in a high school setting. Included is first and last name, gender, class (Freshman, Sophomore, Junior, Senior), and a clique/interest/group that the kid associates with (or is lumped into). Perfect for a variety of modern settings– from light hearted to teen drama to crime, also good for low level supers (particularly teen supers), teenage horror heroes/vampire killers. Also usable for early post apocalypse settings, zombie outbreaks, and/or some cyberpunk/dystopia use. Basically if you need teens and it would be good to know what clique they fit into (or didn’t) here is the list for you...

boardgame.name: 100 High School Kids 15
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This list contains 100 different kids you would find in a high school setting. Included is first and last name, gender, class (Freshman, Sophomore, Junior, Senior), and a clique/interest/group that the kid associates with (or is lumped into). Perfect for a variety of modern settings– from light hearted to teen drama to crime, also good for low level supers (particularly teen supers), teenage horror heroes/vampire killers. Also usable for early post apocalypse settings, zombie outbreaks, and/or some cyberpunk/dystopia use. Basically if you need teens and it would be good to know what clique they fit into (or didn’t) here is the list for you...

boardgame.name: 50 Modern Suburb Residents 4
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This list contains 50 different residents and homes that are perfect for a modern suburbia (notably United States) environment. Included in each entry are the following: Name of home owner(s), total number of occupants (presented as Oc#: #), style of home (craftsman, neo-classical, cape cod, etc.), number of bedrooms and bathrooms, and a brief descriptive of either the yard or interior of home (rose bushes, air hockey table, etc.). Perfect for quickly fleshing out modern neighborhoods from crime/drama settings, super hero settings, early zombie outbreak, early apocalypse, etc.

boardgame.name: 100 Roaring Twenties Bystanders
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This list contains 100 different innocent(?) bystanders that are perfect for a RoaringTwenties rpg campaign setting. Included in each entry is a first and last name, gender, age, and role/occupation.

boardgame.name: King's Road Toll Station
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The river meanders through the forest, passing wildflowers of various colors and cliffs worn away over the ages. A small dock has been built here, a location to pick up supplies from the northland before traveling further into the woods along the now worn trade road.

The road climbs a small embankment and crosses over the stream via a natural bridge, on the other side a small toll station awaits. The king’s men collect tolls here to help maintain the road as well as pay mercenaries or other folk to help patrol it.

boardgame.name: Ravenswood Toll Station
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The boggy stream slowly meanders through this forest, the skeletons of those whom didn’t make it creating it’s riverbed. You pass dreary trees and ferns and cliffs worn away over the ages. A small dock has been built here, a location to pick up supplies from the northland before traveling further into the woods along the now worn trade road.

The road climbs a small embankment and crosses over the stream via a natural bridge, on the other side a small toll station awaits. The king’s men collect tolls here to help maintain the road as well as pay mercenaries or other folk to help patrol it.

boardgame.name: Endangered Orphans: House of Rath
boardgame.description:
Though Endangered Orphans: House of Rath is not a sequel to Certifiable Studios’ freshman project, Endangered Orphans of Condyle Cove, it does occupy the same world.

The game’s (very dark) heart is still the same as its predecessor: Players are trying to keep their orphan(s) safe from a boogeyman. Unfortunately, that means sometimes throwing the other orphans under the proverbial bus.

House of Rath differs significantly in its gameplay, however. It combines elements of deduction, “take that,” and map reduction to create suspense, but the real difference lies in one key point: During every turn, you’re playing as both the orphans and the boogeyman!

During the Roll phase, you’ll do whatever it takes to protect your orphans from the dreaded boogeyman, Count Rath: lock doors, rotate rooms, travel via secret passages, and even reveal other hidden orphans. Every decision could be the one that takes your orphans to (relative) safety—or straight into Rath’s greedy clutches.

You’ll then use the Boogeyman Phase of your turn (while playing as Rath) to suss out which orphans belong to whom, all while steering Rath clear of your orphans (and keeping secret which ones are your orphans when possible).

If one of your orphans is discovered by Rath, your chances of getting away are slim. But hey…a chance is a chance, right? You’ll either escape (likely to be pursued again at a later time) or come to a grisly end and draw a Run Away card.

Though a Run Away card won’t help you when it’s drawn, it’ll give you options later. Use it to give your other orphans better odds of escaping if they’re discovered, or use the card’s one-of-a-kind special ability.

The last player with at least one surviving orphan is the winner!

boardgame.name: The Planarch Vault
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

Created as a joint venture between the gnolgi and the templars, the Planarch Vault is a prison complex and archive for monsters and treasures too powerful to keep anywhere else.

It has been overtaken by two of its worst inmates: a villain from another reality and a horde of quasi-mechanical shapeshifters. The shapeshifters want to cause as much trouble as possible; the villain intends to use the shapeshifters as a distraction to escape and fulfil their own agenda.

The vault’s path has taken it within an inch of the capital; only to land a few leagues south in the wetlands. The templars have mobilised to secure their secrets and discover the fate of the wardens within.

boardgame.name: The G√ºlish Choir
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

Below the ancient Prosperity of Güle lies a warren of ancient caverns and crypts. In here roam the undead spirits of the cities' most villainous prisoners. They are cursed with eternal
unlife; their deeds, and the ancient magic of this place, ensure they may never again know the joy of life nor the peace of death.

Now, the Choir has caught the scent of a mortal soul for the first time in decades. Yours.

boardgame.name: The Broken Demon
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

Desolate forest and leagues of unkempt road have led you to the gates of Littlestone. Tallrock Mountain looms behind it, filling your vision. The sheer immensity of it makes these rugged old-stone houses seem smaller, less relevant; insignificant motes in the great span of time.

The artist and his wife greet you at the door. The wife you know, from way back. The artist you don’t, save by reputation. He looks at you askance; your senses flash cold for a moment. The feeling passes, but you keep your guard.

“They came from underneath,” the wife is telling you. “The old ruins, the ones we built the houses on... they’re haunted. Now, those things live there.”

The basement beckons, a yawning chasm, cold as the grave. It swallows you whole.

“Will you go down there? Now? I wouldn’t normally insist, but they always come out after dark...”

What do you do?

boardgame.name: Pinnacles of Opulence
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

The spires of the city are flawed jewels. The palace is a haven for the obscenely rich, in a city wracked by disease and famine. As times have grown worse, these great houses have become quieter - save the wealthiest of the city elite.

But today it is busy; a mysterious urn for sale at auction has caught the attention of many. Rich and poor, healthy and sick, lawful and chaotic. Who will claim the vase, and the greater prize within? And what will they do with it?

boardgame.name: Corpseglade
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

Once, long ago, stood a city of man. It was proud, and it was mighty. The merchants grew wealthy; the lawmen kept the peace; the priests counselled wisdom. It was a fine place.

Today, it is an overgrown ruin. There was a war, the story goes; the Sidhe queen coveted the soil the city was built on. Her servants hold leaf-choked court over the remains. The streets are naught but weeds. Between claustrophobic copses of greenery, you may spy a weathered hunk of granite or exposed foundation. Where men once walked, there are only the trees, and the unseelie things that live among them.

They say the Cities’ Dead sleep poorly here. And why shouldn’t they? Ousted from their homes by nature itself. It is said the last men of the city swore they would see Death’s Black Gates remade from black bark and fair-folk sap. And thus began the second great war, and the forest that was a city earned the name of Corpseglade.

Yet even stories of the second war are old, by mortal reckoning. The forces of life and death reached a stalemate in their eternal, quiet war. But unknown to all, a third player has entered the stage. No matter the victor, the Servants of Rot see a grand opportunity. If the dead succeed, there shall be an army of the restless dead to enslave. If nature prevails, it will mean a near-limitless supply of fresh life to corrupt. No matter the victor, it seems, mortal life stands to lose. And now fate or circumstance brings the adventurers to Corpseglade. What will happen next, I wonder?

boardgame.name: Hunter's Cove
Hunters Cove
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

[25 years ago:] Hunter’s Cove is founded. Over the following years, what little sea travel reaches Dragonspine finds its way here. The port gains a reputation for ignoring the requests of the Four Courts, no matter how reasonable. Railsmark refuses to negotiate a trade deal despite the Kingsroad that connects the two cities.

boardgame.name: A Humble Vine
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

The groundskeeper leads you downstairs, past dusty halls and mouldering furniture. “I’d apologise for your meager dinner” says he, “but I’ve more pressing work for ye. The old man is... indisposed towards saving this here vineyard of his. Reckon the life went out of him when his lass died, poor thing. But I still take some pride in this place.”

He rambles on. There’s an infection, he claims, at the heart of this vineyard. A horde of goblins, and worse things, he fears. He wants them all gone so he can restore the vineyard.

You come to your destination - a loamy hole cut rudely into the cellar wall. The air here is wet, and very still. He ushers you forward, down the slippery path. Against your better judgment you press on, feet slipping on the slimy, broken stones. The groundskeeper does not follow.

boardgame.name: A Bridge to Nowhere
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

The bonfire is as big as a house. The ash and smoke covers everything, stinging your eyes and blurring your vision. The only villagers you find are dead. In the centre of the town, a Wolftusk raider (most likely the warband’s leader) is quietly admiring the devastation. Others are surely nearby, likely picking through the ruins.

Felstead is (was) not a big village, perhaps home to a dozen or so families. All of them are missing, save the grisly corpses on the fire. You were hoping to stop here to catch some rest and supplies. That will not be the case now.

boardgame.name: A Long Lonesome Road
A Long, Lonesome Road
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

The winter season has been cold and tedious. As spring approaches, talk in the town turns to thoughts of new horizons - and opportunities...

boardgame.name: The Green Blood of Dry'cho'basz
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

The mood on the ship was dour on the way back.

The wind was calm, almost too calm to coax the sails home. The skies were the colour of frozen ash. The salt water of the open waves stung cheeks; the grey skies cast a bitter mood across the deck. Below, the groans of the wounded were louder than the creaks of the battered timbers.

Those that could caught scant hours of sleep. They tried to forget the ignominy of returning in defeat; the cries of their fellow kinsmen as they fell in battle; the blood, the mud, and the stink of sulphur over torrid jungle. They hoped they could find solace in their loved ones upon their return; that this care would not be outweighed by the shame and disgrace of their defeat. Some were more confident in this than others.

boardgame.name: The Mirkasa Chronicles
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

“...And so, the adventurers travelled north to frosty MIRKASA, a chilled and grim land. Would the warriors brave the minotaur lords of the mountain peaks, the enigmatic forces in the forests, or the evil presence lurking in the mines? And when they returned to town to reap their reward, would they be treated as heroes - or heretics?”

The Mirkasa Chronicles is a winter-themed adventure setting for Dungeon World. It introduces a ton of monsters, factions, locations and characters ready to use as they are or remix into your own adventures, including:

The Templar of Mirka - an all-new custom class for Dungeon World, based on a more grim'n'gritty take on the typical faith-based hero.
The City of Nosjad - people, places and things to do in this stark wintry city
3 Encounters, collected and remixed here from my Patreon for the first time: Failspeake Gorge, A Stench in Nosjad, and fan-favourite The Planarch Vault;
Tables, tables, tables! Names, flora, fauna, gear, and more!

boardgame.name: Extinction Lab
boardgame.description:
Dinosaurs are being tested in a top secret lab, by a few trusted scientists, when all goes dark. As the lights flicker on, each scientist discovers themselves in a separate room, manipulating their dinosaur as well as the Lab itself through a strange bracelet fused to their wrist. Their goal: make it to the Lab Exit before the other scientists, at all costs.

Gameplay of Extinction Lab consists of each player taking a turn, on which they:

Decide to either move all their dinos on the board OR roll the die to take actions.
If they decided to roll the die, they receive 1-3 actions, depending upon what was rolled.
Individual actions are spent on moving your Scientist, using your Scientists ability, attacking an enemy dino or Scientist, using a telepad, using a gear card, or drawing and resolving a Direction card (Direction cards allow a player to shift the Lab tiles).


To win, your Scientist must be on the Lab Exit with a Lab Key in hand.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Traps
boardgame.description:
In Traps, players take control of a team of two unique adventurers. Each team is desperate to escape the jungle the first.

-You’ll use a variety of cards and special abilities to make it happen.
-Draw from hundreds of unique cards to help you make your escape
-Use your characters’ special abilities to incite game changing moments
-Plan your perfect strategy (and a few backup strategies) to stay one step ahead

Card Types:

TRAPS: Place these cards directly on the board to stop your enemies dead in their tracks, wipe out their funds, or just generally cause chaos.

ACTIONS: Play these super-powered cards right from your hand. They’ll help you tilt the game in your favor—from blocking Traps to giving you special perks that last all game.

MONEY PITS: These Traps are all about the money. When an opponent lands on one, they pay you. When you land on one, the bank pays you. It’s a win-win.

FOUND TREASURE: These cards help you accrue sweet, sweet cash to fund your wildest dreams and schemes. You’ve just got to be lucky enough to draw one.

Each turn consists of rolling and moving, drawing cards (see above), and playing those cards with devastating effect.

These cards reshape the jungle with each playthrough so that no two games are ever the same.

Beyond cards, one of the primary game mechanics is character abilities. These let you perform unique actions such as stealing a ton of extra cash from your foes to dodging a Trap at the last minute.

There are 8 characters (4 humans and 4 animals). Each team is made up of a randomly paired human and animal duo. Since every character has their own ability, you never know what combo (and strategy) you’ll end up with.

Along the way you’ll encounter spaces that protect you, beef up your wallet, or poison you, severely setting your progress back.

Nothing is truly as it seems in this jungle. So be warned: Trust no one. Trap everyone.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Asking for Trobils: Companions
boardgame.description:
Companions is an expansion to "Asking for Trobils".

Space is lonely, but when the lost colony ship, the Friend, appeared on the outskirts of the star system, everyone was thrilled to hear about it. Even more exciting, the Friend Ship contains a new resource, Shards, that provides another way to capture Trobils!

The residents of this ship are eager to explore the galaxy with you. If you let them tag along, despite their silly quirks, they'll give you these Shards to help rid the galaxy of Trobils.

Companion cards are randomly paired with a Shard card and placed in a new player board that includes a Dial. The Dial helps show players where to place Shards and points to the active Quirk of the Companion.

These pairs of cards are obtained by visiting the Friend Ship location. Shards are valuable, so players will strategize how to best navigate the Quirks of their Companion in order to gain as many Shards as they can without interrupting the efficiency of their Trobil hunting.
boardgame.boardgameaccessory: Asking for Trobils: The Big Box

boardgame.name: The Magnificent: SN√ò
boardgame.description:
The audience holds their breath as she breaks the darkness, piercing the silence like an icicle, whirling up the frozen saw dust like a massive blizzard. She is the Magnificent SNØ.

This expansion to The Magnificent introduces SNØ, a new performer with her own camp tiles and poster cards.
You can now play the game with up to 5 players. New master cards provide new types of bonuses and new ways to score. New trainer tiles provide new ways to tweak your actions. The optional Master Board Module gives each player a special action each round, and then there is more. Note that the base game is required to play!

8 new Trainer Tiles

Components for the 5th player

-description from designer

listing.notes: New in shrink.

boardgame.name: Delores: A Thimbleweed Park Mini-Adventure
boardgame.description:
Delores is back home and working as a photographer for the Nickel News. Thimbleweed Park hasn’t changed at all in the year she’s been away… or has it? Sample Ron Gilbert’s new adventure game engine in this free prototype that uses "found art" from the award-winning Thimbleweed Park.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Pixel Dorks
boardgame.description:
Pixel Dorks is an action/strategy duel for 2 players
For eons, the Red and Blue Dorks coexisted in harmony, until one fateful day, a joint team of Dorks of both colors made an imaginary and nonsensical scientific breakthrough. They discovered the underlying building block of all life -- The Pixel. Harnessing the power of the Pixels allowed the Dorks to manipulate reality at its most basic levels, permitting magical feats of greatness. As the Dorks are vaguely human-like, war inevitably ensued.

You control Mages battling each other for control of Towers, because that's where they store their Pixels, I guess. Use your imagination, do I have to do everything?

Summon and command your Minions.

Upgrade your Mage into a force to be reckoned with.

Cast spells and time the use of your special Powers to overcome your enemy.

Take Control of all the Mage Towers to win!

Gameplay Features:
Grid movement on a Map of Terrain with varied effects
Flip & Write
Hand-drawn Pixel Art
Large variety of Spell cards
Big Player Mats
8 characters with unique abilities
8 different Maps to play on

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Arkenshield: The Gates of Thy'an
boardgame.description:
The royal city of Thaera´Ijun is the starting point of your expedition all the way across the continent. From here, you’ll set out to face thrilling adventures and perilous challenges. You’ll pass by endless grassy plains, advance into the depths of impenetrable forests, traverse the Obsidian Islands of the Westbound Reach, enter the legendary City of Outer Sands, leave the hostile Great Salt Desert behind you, walk the mysterious Nowhere Trail, find a way through Stonewalled Lives and finally – after slipping past the great Ice Wall and its dangerous narrow places – arrive, emaciated and exhausted, at the foot of the mighty fortress in the ice. And here, your greatest test awaits you.

Gather Companions around you, overcome epic tests and vanquish the mighty walls of the Citadel. Always remember: In the contest to conquer it, you’re competing with other fellowships. It isn’t the first player to get hold of the Crown of the Princes of the Northern Lands who’ll definitely be able to claim the glory of victory, but the one who, using a well-thought-out strategy, captures treasures (Victory Points) and valuable objects (cards) at the right points in the game.

Arkenshield is a turn-based, – deck building – boardgame for 1 to 4 players. It combines components of a boardgame with those of a card game. Thanks to the large number of Companions, movement tokens, cards, and events, it’s never boring, as it offers new and different possibilities – especially in interaction with other players. The use of dice is explicitly avoided. Instead, it is more important to succeed with your strategic abilities.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Capital Lux 2: Pocket
boardgame.description:
This pocket edition is a conveniently portable and slightly trimmed version of the big box game, Capital Lux 2 : Generations.

Capital Lux 2: Pocket, a standalone sequel to the acclaimed tactical card game from 2016, introduces a range of exchangeable capital powers that can be mixed and matched as you like. This allows for a total of 81 unique power combinations. One of these combinations plays as the original Capital Lux, while the other 80 present the players new tactical challenges.

The core of the game revolves around the following dilemma: Do you play character cards in your home base for points, or contribute them to the capital to benefit from their powers? At the end of a round, you are not allowed to have a higher total value in your home base for any color than the current total value in the capital. Exceeding the limit makes you lose those cards. At the end of the third round, all cards remaining in your home base are worth points.

The game therefore turns into an act of balancing on a razor's edge: Secure as many points for yourself without exceeding the capital's limit — always taking into account the current capital powers.

Contains:
160 cards
40 tiles and tokens

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Die Axt im Walde
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb

In the small barony Ambelmund the Efferdfest is celebrated. Jugglers, minstrels and showmen entertain the visitors, knights, warriors and other fighters compete in the tournament for gold, fame and honour. The highlight of the festivities is a swimming competition for Efferd's fame.

But not everyone can enjoy the joyful activity. Befinna, the Baroness's younger sister, longs to escape the constraints of her status and the walls of the palace. She yearns for the freedom of the woods, for a romantic nature. But above all, she wants to escape the Horasian groom chosen for her by her sister. Trapped between two apparently irreconcilable worlds, she seeks support to follow her longing.

Helpful heroes are soon confronted with unyielding points of view and can influence the future of Nordgratenfels as the much-invoked tip of the scales.


Klappentext

In der kleinen Baronie Ambelmund wird das Efferdfest gefeiert. Gaukler, Spielleute und Schausteller unterhalten die Besucher, Recken, Ritter und andere Kämpfer fechten im Turnier um Gold, Ruhm und Ehre. Höhepunkt der Feierlichkeiten ist ein Wettschwimmen zum Ruhme Efferds.

Doch nicht jeder kann das freudige Treiben genießen. Befinna, die jüngere Schwester der Baronin, sehnt sich danach, den Zwängen ihres Standes und den Mauern des Palastes zu entkommen. Sie verzehrt sich nach der Freiheit der Wälder, nach romantischer Natur. Vor allem jedoch möchte sie dem horasischen Bräutigam entkommen, den ihre Schwester für sie ausgewählt hat. Zwischen zwei augenscheinlich unvereinbaren Welten gefangen, sucht sie nach Unterstützung, um ihrer Sehnsucht folgen zu können.

Hilfsbereite Helden werden bald mit unnachgiebigen Standpunkten konfrontiert und können als das vielbeschworene Zünglein an der Waage Einfluss auf die Zukunft von Nordgratenfels nehmen.

boardgame.name: Benidorm Bar Crawl
boardgame.description:
Build your Benidorm Empire as you acquire bars, add shows & obtain hotel partnership deals to maximise the spend per visit for each of your venues until the other players go bust and you own it all.

Purchase bars as you land on them then then increase the income you receive per visit by adding shows and hotel partnership deals.

Shows can be purchased and added to any of your bars immediately and can be moved between your venues each turn.

Hotel partnership deals can be purchased when you have 4 or more bars in the same district that will multiply your bar's earnings.

When you land on an area with Jager Bombs you must draw a card from the 'Power of Jager' deck which have good or bad consequences.

Benidorm Bucks are the in-game currency that is used to trade venues, shows, contracts & pay bar fees as the bar crawl continues.

Props can be employed and placed at any bars when you own the bar next door, visitors must then visit both bars on the same turn.

Preparation
To begin, place the game board on the table. Each player selects a player piece. All players then place their player piece on the cash point square of the outta section of the game board. All players roll the dice, the player with the highest dice roll is the Banker, who distributes assets from the Bank to the players. Each player is given 3,000 in cash divided as follows: two 500s, ten 100s, ten 50s and twenty five 20s. All remaining cash and other equipment go to the Bank.

General
On a player’s turn, the player roll the dice and move his/her player piece forward the number of spaces as rolled on the dice. If the player owns any Shows or Props, they can move these between their owned bars during their turn.
If the player lands on an unowned bar, the player may buy it for the price listed on that bar’s space. The money is given to the Bank in exchange for the Property Acquired Card for that premises. Shows can be purchased immediately and added to the premies, increasing its earn when visited. Props can be added when a player owns 2 properties next to each other and Hotel Deals can be purchased when a player owns 4 properties in the same district (colour).
When players land on a property owned by another player, they must pay the player the amount stated on the Property Acquired Card including extra charges if the premises has Shows or Hotel Deal added.
If the player lands on his or her own property, nothing happens.
When players land on Lotto spaces they must contribute 100 Benidorm Bucks to the prize pool in the centre of the board, any fines, the money will be also added to this prize pool.
When players land on Jager spaces, they must draw a card from the Power of Jager Deck, this will either have good or bad consequences.
If the player is sent to ‘The Beach’ to sleep it off, they must roll above a 6 to wake up and continue playing, unless they have an ‘Energy Drink’ card to play.
If the player lands on ‘The Beach’ space, he or she is “Just Passing Through”. No penalty applies.
If the player lands on the ‘Spin Out’, he or she must move his Player Piece directly to ‘The Beach’.
Every time a player passes a Cash Point they collect 200 Benidorm Bucks from the Banker.
You may sell Shows or Props back to the Bank for the full purchase price or sell properties to other players via mutual agreement at any point during the game.
Players can loan other players money and make agreements during the game.
Doubles
When doubles are rolled, the player gets to play again during the same turn.

The Beach
If instructed to ‘Go to the Beach to sleep it off’ via either landing on the space stating that or drawing a Jager Card with that instruction, the player must enter the beach and roll above a 6 to continue playing, they can try once per turn.

Whilst passed out on the beach, if other players enter ‘The Beach’, just passing through, they can challenge the player for a bar of their choice, each, and the higher roller wins both bars.

Lotto
Ant ime a player lands on a Lotto space, they must pay 100 Benidorm bucks to the Prize Pool in the center of the game board.

Bottom Line
Each turn, try to foresee where players will land after your turn to maximise income and bankrupt your competitors.

boardgame.name: Sharn: City of Blood!
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

It's arcanopulp intrigue in this Eberron mystery!
A pulp adventure designed for characters of 3rd to 5th level. Est. playtime 5-8 hours, depending on your table.

Warforged private detective Steel-Eye Dixon has caught a case, just not in a manner he's accustomed to. After begging for his help, a would-be client has turned up dead. Stranger still, multiple murders across Sharn could also be connected. Can the characters uncover the truth in the City of Towers?

boardgame.name: Liber Genus I: Medusa
Medusa
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Medusas are expert infiltrators, with a head of snakes for hair.

Many people know the medusas are horrific monsters that can turn you to stone with a glance, yet few know that medusas are fairly prevalent within settlements and organisations throughout the world. Due to their reputation medusas hide their true identities from everyone, secretly moving their way up the leadership ladder of any organisation they infiltrate. They prefer to use poison over their petrifying gaze, although now and again an adversary proves too troublesome or intelligent to succumb to the indirect method.

boardgame.name: Liber Genus III: Nymph
Nymph
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Nymphs are beautiful fey that guard nature from interlopers.

Nymphs are inscrutable protectors of woodland glades, pristine mountain lakes and other natural features. Each type of nymph protects a specific feature, such as naiads who protect pools, ponds and lakes while dryads guard trees and groves.

boardgame.name: Gekitai¬≤
boardgame.description:
Gekitai² ™ (Repel or Push Away) is a 3-in-a-row game played on a 6x6 grid. Each player has sixteen colored markers in two colors and takes turns placing them anywhere on any open space on the board. When placed, a marker pushes all adjacent pieces outwards one space if there is an open space for it to move to (or off the board). Pieces shoved off the board are returned to the player.

If there is not an open space on the opposite side of the pushed piece, it does not push (a newly played piece cannot push two or more other lined-up pieces).

When getting 3-in-a-row or all eight on the board, these are exchanged for upgraded pawns of a different (upgraded) color.

The first player to either line up three of their upgraded colors in a row at the end of their turn (after pushing) OR have all eight of their upgraded markers on the board (also after pushing), is declared the winner.

-description from the designer

boardgame.name: Liber Genus II: Sahuagin
Sahuagin
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This second installment brings the ferocious sahuagin to the table, with rules on how to create a character as an ancestry. Incorporating 3 heritages focusing on their underwater skill and mutations represented by those iwth extra arms and spines along their back as well as 12 ancestry feats, one precious material armour and one weapon.

boardgame.name: BattleTech Science Fiction Combat Book Game: WSP-1A Wasp
boardgame.description:
Type: WSP-1A Wasp
Tonnage: 20 Tons
Engine: 120 GM
Weapons:

Diverse Optics Type 2 Medium Laser
Bical SRM Twin-Rack


The new-made ruins of the city have been unnaturally quiet during your patrol. You alternate between speed and caution, picking slowly through the rubble and then darting across the open spaces. Suddenly, the building beside you explodes from weapons fire. Laser ready, missiles loaded, you leap into the courtyard. Can your speed and agility outwit this unknown foe?

-from back of the book

Type: RFL-3N Rifleman
Tonnage: 60 Tons
Engine: Pitban 240
Weapons:

Two Magna Mk III Heavy Laser
Two Magna Mk II Medium Laser
Two Imperator-A Autocannon


The world you defend is hot, the atmosphere barely breathable. Most 'Mechs dread worlds like this, but you have fewer problems. The combination of large lasers and autocannon allow you to manage your heat buildup better. Suddenly, you spot a gleam of metal in the distance. You on-board computer oes not recognize it as a friend. You fire a burst of lasers . . .

boardgame.name: Fisherman vs Diver
boardgame.description:
"Fisherman vs Diver" is a Dice Draft mechanic game; each player represents a person who lives from the extraction of fish and seafood, where he tries to get more victory points than his opponents, to win the game.

Through the actions you will be able to draw fish or seafood, for this you will need to get resources like bait, oxygen, or energy and in order to fulfill “Purchase Orders” to get victory points.

The game consists on a number of rounds depending on the number of players. During each round, all players choose one die from the available ones and perform the corresponding or optional action. When all the players have played the same number of turns and there is one die left, the round is over.

In the last round, a final count of points is made and the winner of this fisherman vs. diver is revealed.

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: Amabie
„Ç¢„Éû„Éì„Ç®
boardgame.description:
This is a very short card game for two using the Japanese Yokai Amabie as the theme. Amabie first began appearing in Japan in 1846 forecasting 6 years of good harvest followed by a plague. Amabie said "draw me and show me to the people, so that you can be free of disease" according to historical experts.

The game consists of only 6 cards one of which is Amabie. The cards are worth differing points from 0 to 3 (Amabie). Players each look at one card from their hand, the rest remain facedown and then give the other player a card from their hand for 3 rounds. the player at the end with the most points is the winner.

boardgame.name: 5‰∫∫ÁõÆ (Fifth Person)
boardgame.description:
The trick-taking game 5‰∫∫ÁõÆ (Fifth Person) was released as part of the publisher ruri ruri games' („Çã„Çä„Çã„Çä„Ç≤„Éº„É†„Ç∫) Spring 2018 box of trick-taking games, titled „Éà„É™„ÉÜ„Çª„ÉÉ„Éà Vol. 2 (Trick Taking Set Vol. 2).

The game is a cooperative horror trick-taking game set in a mountain cabin. While the game is intended to be played by 4 players, they'll soon find a fifth card has been played to each trick: but by who?

The power is out, and the players must keep a candle from burning out by playing candle-suited cards periodically in the hand.

There is an amulet suit, and players will use these amulets to ward off the mysterious Fifth Person at the end of the game.

The Fifth Person enters the game after the second trick, with their own deck of black cards. If a player wins a trick that contains the Black 9, that player is kidnapped, and cards played to tricks they or the Fifth Person win will not have their affects activated (such as re-lighting the candle.)

At the end of the game, the players win if the candle remains lit and all players have enough amulet to ward of any black cards they obtained. A partial victory is granted if at least one player does not have enough amulets. All players lose if the candle goes out.

boardgame.name: Marvel Battlebooks: Shi
boardgame.description:
Two cards were bound into the comic book. One listed the rules and identified the features of the game. The second card was the character's Maneuver Card which listed the actions the character could take in combat.

Gameplay was similar to Lost Worlds. Each player picks a character and game books are exchanged so each player has a book that depicts POV illustrations of the opponent attacking. Maneuvers are simultaneously selected and the matrix encoded into the books determines the results of each exchange.

Shi was #6 in the series.

boardgame.name: Warhammer Warriors: Tyranid Warrior
boardgame.description:
A Warhammer version of Lost Worlds based on Games Workshop's 40,000 setting. Each player uses a battle book and chooses a page number for a maneuver for their turn. These are revealed simultaneously and cross-referenced. A chart then shows you which page to turn to see the results of the maneuvers. Players usually end up wounded or in a better position to strike a killing blow.

Warhammer Warriors is slightly more stream-lined than Lost Worlds and plays faster. Warhammer Warriors does not have "behind you" maneuvers and there is a lot more shooting/ranged combat. All characters have a Deathblow maneuver which speed up games if you're in a good position.

Tyranid Warrior is number #6 in the series.

boardgame.description:
7 Wonders
The board game with more awards than any other game on the planet.
With over 30 international awards, and over a million copies sold throughout the world, rediscover 7 Wonders, the game which has won more awards than any other game in the world, in a whole new version. Lauded by both the public and critics, 7 Wonders has claimed its place as an unmissable reference point in modern board gaming. 7 Wonders is based on a simple and elegant mechanic (drafting) which allows up to 7 players to play with no dead time. Players make their choice and apply all of them at the same time. These choices are varied and their impact is real. Finally, the game is divided into 3 Ages which little by little increase the importance of these choices and thus the tension in the game. The global mechanics and the care given to the artwork are used to immerse the player in Antiquity and have contributed to the game’s success.
A game plays out over 3 rounds, called Ages, during which you simultaneously play cards, one at a time, to develop your City.

These cards represent the various Buildings you can construct: resource producers, civilian, commercial, military, scientific structures, and guilds.

At the end of each Age, you go to war with your nearest neighbours. At the end of all 3 Ages, you tally up all of the victory points earned by your City, your wonder, your military prowess, and your treasury. The player with the highest score wins the game.

Content:
7 Wonder boards
148 Age cards: 49 Age I cards, 49 Age II cards, and 50 Age III cards
78 Coins: 54 Coins of value 1, and 24 Coins of value 3
48 Military Conflict tokens: 24 Defeats and 24 Victories (8 per Age)
1 pad of score sheets
3 quick reference sheets describing the effects of the cards
1 List of cards and chaining leaflet
1 rulebook

This is a combined version that takes the best of the first and second edition. Almost all of the material is obviously from the second edition. Tokens are edge painted. It uses the 1E version instead of the 2E version of the: Box (smaller but still fits everything) Instructions (to fit in the box, but it includes the 2E player aids) Military Tokens (they look better)
It also includes: The 8th armada board (was removed in V2) and enough plastic ships to play 8 players. The 3 wonders from the 1E wonder pack that were not brought over to 2E are included. All the cards that were present in the first edition that were removed in the second edition are included.

boardgame.description:
7 Wonders – Cities
Discover the secrets of millennia-old cities
In the dark alleyways of your city, gold changes hands, alliances are made and secrets are betrayed... Now your influence extends to the heart of rival cities. But take care, their spies plot within your walls! In addition to two new Wonders and the ability to play in teams, this expansion offers you a new type of cards: Cities. Mercenaries, thieves, spies, and diplomats will give new interactions in your games.
Debts, looting, diplomacy… thanks to this 7 Wonders expansion, you can discover another aspect of the great cities of Antiquity.

The 42 new Age cards as well as the 2 new Wonders offer you brand-new effects. The Cities expansion brings new rules to the 7 Wonders base game, but the victory conditions remain identical.

This expansion also offers you a variant which allows you to play in teams (with 4 or 6 players). The main addition of Cities is an increased interaction between players as well as the addition of debts.

7 Wonders Cities is an independent expansion but is compatible with the other expansions for 7 Wonders.

Content:
2 Wonder boards
42 Cities cards (14 per Age)
26 debt tokens
4 diplomacy tokens
1 pad of score sheets
3 quick reference sheets describing the new effects
1 rulebook

boardgame.name: Mask of the God-Emperor
boardgame.description:
"A break-in at the mausoleum of the ancient God-Emperor Shummanla-shamash brings the party face-to-face with undead Yuan-ti raised to rob the tomb. The burial mask that held a spark of the god-emperor’s divine essence has been stolen, and the ghost of the god-emperor himself asks the party to return it to the tomb before the thief can steal its divine power for themselves. The party’s investigation leads them into the deadly in-fighting between the local Yuan-ti cults, pitting them against a heretic necromancer who will stop at nothing to subjugate his abominable kin.

Mask of the God-Emperor is a D&D 5e one-shot adventure for a party of 4 characters levels 3-5."

(Author Summary)

boardgame.description:
7 Wonders – Leaders
Play with the personalities of Antiquity
At the heart of your city, exceptional men and women inspire your people and lead your civilization to its apogee. Choose them with care and they will contribute to your greatness. Neglect them and they will end up at the head of rival cities! In addition to two new Wonders, this expansion offers you a new type of card: Leader cards. Queens, astronomers, philosophers, and generals will all bring extra strategic dimensions to your games.
This 7 Wonders expansion offers you the ability to place renowned personalities at the head of your civilization: Leaders.

Represented by 55 new cards, they will influence, each in their own way, the development of your City.

The Leaders expansion adds new rules to those of the 7 Wonders base game, but the victory conditions remain the same.

You’ll start your games with a choice of Leaders who, each in their own way, will influence your city for the rest of the game.

7 Wonders Leaders is an independent expansion but which is compatible with the other expansions for 7 Wonders.

Content:
2 Wonder boards
49 Leader cards divided into 2 decks (Standard and Expert)
6 bonus cards for the Cities expansion
18 coins
1 pad of score sheets
3 quick reference sheets describing the new effects
1 rulebook

boardgame.description:
7 Wonders – Armada
Take command of a fleet of ships
The horizon is now within reach, your armada waits only on you to go conquer the seas! On board your ships, discover faraway isles, trade with remote cities, and equip your fleets to prepare for the naval conflict to come… In addition to a new Wonder, this expansion allows you to expand your interactions with two new types of cards: Armada cards and Isle cards. Navigators, explorers, shipowners, and pirates will give new depth to your games.
This 7 Wonders expansion allows you to conquer the seas thanks to individual boards: Shipyards.

The 24 new Age cards and 27 new Isle cards enrich the game and allow new interactions between players.

The Armada expansion adds new rules to the base 7 Wonders game, but the victory conditions remain the same. Your fleets, represented by small colored ships, represent your advance.

This expansion also offers you a variant which allows you to play in teams (with 4 or 6 players).

7 Wonders Armada is an independent expansion but is compatible with the other expansions for 7 Wonders.

1 Wonder board
7 Shipyard boards
28 Flotilla miniatures (4 per player)

22 Naval Victory tokens
18 Naval Defeat tokens

4 Military Victory tokens
4 Military Defeat tokens
2 Incursion tokens
6 Coins of value 6
24 Armada cards (8 per Age)
27 Isle cards (9 per level)
1 pad of score sheets
3 quick reference sheets describing the new effects
1 rulebook

boardgame.name: Footballiser
boardgame.description:
The hottest football game not just for football fans! Footballiser is a board game in which you can conquer the world of football as both a team leader, club owner and a football player. A game where you not only get to use your strategic skills alongside your dexterity, but also have to exploit both if you want to win the cup!

The objective of Footballiser is to be the first player to obtain all 6 Stadium Development Items and to win the league final! Footballiser is a turn-based game, meaning in each round players get to decide what action(s) to take. Each round comprises two phases: using of an Action Card and carrying out an operation. An operation may be opting for a Stadium or Team Development (either via trading in trophies previously won for successful matches, or by rolling the Development Dice), or playing a match.

Stadium Development Items are to be put on one’s Development Board, except at the start all 6 sections of the Development Board are occupied by a certain number of flags. To remove flags and therefore to make place for possible Stadium Developments, one has to win matches. When it comes to playing matches, a player has to draw a Match Cards. Match Cards come in four different difficulty levels, often depicting famous football situations. All 50 Match Cards are unique, providing you a pool of possibilities that would be extremely hard to get bored of. The Footballiser Field consist of numbered cells, making Match Cards easily understandable, and the footballer figures easily placeable on the board. One must flick the figures in a way that the figures push to ball to a selected few cells that count as a successful pass, and repeat the process a few times to kick the ball through the goal line.

After winning the match, the player gets to decide which section to free up for Stadium Development, although it shall not be random, as the usage of Action Cards and Power Cards are often conditioned on a certain level of Stadium Development. Power Cards provide you with a higher chance of winning matches, for example by allowing you to try again certain shots or skip otherwise necessary passes on your way to the goal. Action Cards either provide help for your development in game, or offer up an opportunity to set someone else’s development back, for example by having them put Development Items back in the pack or by making them skip turns or limiting their choice when their turn comes. If all the flags are taken off of the Development Board, all Stadium Development Items are placed on their rightful places on the Development Board, you may proceed to play the league final. When you win that, you win the game.

boardgame.name: RuneSword: Endril ‚Äì Elfin Archer with Epee
boardgame.description:
A thematic series in the Lost Worlds series (these books are even compatible with the others). Players each take a character represented with a game book and a stat sheet. By giving the book to the opposite player, the pages give a first person view to the combatants. As various moves direct the players to turn to this page or that, combat damage, restrictions, and other special events are relayed to the players via the pages of the book.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.

boardgame.name: Midnight Murder Mysteries (Second Edition)
Minuit, Meurtre en Mer (2nde √©dition)
boardgame.description:
MIDNIGHT: TIME OF THE MURDER!

Aboard the Majestic, the lifeless body of a passenger has been found in their luxury suite... The prime suspects are the twelve occupants of the VIP cabins on the upper deck. You and your fellow private detectives are attending a conference on board, and place a wager to reconstruct the circumstances of the alleged crime before the ship reaches the port!

WHO IS THE MURDERER? WHAT WAS THEIR MOTIVE?
HOW DID THE VICTIM DIE?

This game box contains a large number of unique cases. In each case, you can interrogate each of the 12 suspects on 3 conversation topics, and search for clues at 24 locations on various decks of the ship.

3 different game modes are included: competitive, cooperative, and solo!

boardgame.name: I Love Britain
boardgame.description: Are you familiar with red telephone boxes, "Nessie" and crumpets? Roll the die to see whether you're moving around by bicycle, by car or by plane. Correctly answer questions in each of the five different categories to win the game.

ÌîΩÏÖÄ ÏΩîÎìú
boardgame.description:
Youngil was an ordinary student who enjoyed playing computer games. One day, he was trapped in cyberspace and can only escape by making binary numbers.

Roll the dice and flip your personal binary numbers cards by the number shown on the dice. If you can match the decimal numbers in the centre of the board then collect the matched cards. Each card is worth a point, plus any bonus points shown. At the end of the game, flip your score cards over and see if you can match a bonus pattern for extra points.

boardgame.name: Wreck of the Windfall
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

5th Edition Mini-Dungeon for four to six characters of levels 5-6

Caught in a sudden storm not far from port, the merchant ship Windfall went down with all hands.

To make matters worse, stowed below deck were the last remnants of the necromancer Vorphanos. The fear and anger of the dying sailors mixed with the power of these accursed relics, caused their spirits to stay tethered to the ship as incorporeal undead, even though their bodies were taken by the sea.

Divers have been scared off by reports of a giant shark in the area (even unaware of the supernatural dangers), so a local salvager turns to the characters to recover the ship’s cargo. Their employer can provide the characters with a water breathing ritual.

boardgame.name: Faerie War Arrows Hit Death!
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

5th Edition Mini-Dungeon for four to five characters of levels 18-20

The module begins in a great city, such as planar Elemenopolis.

On crossing a marketplace, a sandy-haired outcrier catches your ear; “Faerie War Arrows Hit Death!” He is handing out printed sheets. Spotting you, he approaches; “Friends, this may interest those seeking intrigue!”

The human-looking hawker is Embirikos, an androsphinx. He hands them a sheet from the back of his stack. Embirikos seeks to use the party to intervene in a conflict between shadow fey and fiends. When read, the keysheets teleports the party to a planar conflux beneath the city. If assailed, Embirikos uses his Teleport legendary action, targets keysheet carriers with three Roars, and then leaves the area. The keysheet reads:

“Award Faerie’s arrow the hit!
The heated warrior was fair.
Area drifters who hear, wait;
If warier, others award hate!
With Death, worries are afar.”
For one “to free” five – Embirikos

boardgame.name: Legendary Wizards
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Master of the Arcane Arts

Legendary Wizards is the latest volume in our new series of class-focused player supplements, this time focusing on the cleverest and most magic-savvy of of all classes, the mighty wizard! This core class is the quintessential arcane spellcaster, a master of knowledge and magic that commanded the full might of the unknown at their fingertips. This book is intended to help expand the wizard further with a redesign of the class which seeks to grant new options to further help you expand upon your mastery of the arcane. Legendary Wizards is intended to help take wizards from just a way to cast spells into a proper font of arcane knowledge with Path of the Mage giving unique options on how to cast spells from memory or otherwise, Arcane Discoveries to further help you customize your mage’s powers, and Genius Insight to help show that arcane brilliance and prevail in even the most dire of circumstances. n addition, new archetypes allow you to take up strange new powers with Drake Maverick granting you the power of a mighty drake companion, Master of Undeath allowing you to fully tap into the powers of life and death, and Gunpowder Mage perfectly marrying the explosive power of firearms with the mystic arts of the arcane.

boardgame.name: Time Manipulation
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Crucible Mage is a wizard who has released themself from their limited perception of time. Rather than view it from only the present they look through the eyes of their past and future self to better prepare, recall lost information and act in the now, but then. The subclass is an arcane tradition that opens up options regarding spell preperation, setting up spells to cast in advance and overcoming surprise by seeing such events ahead of time.
